column1: The first settlers of Fair Lawn were members of the Lenni Lenape tribe
column2: a peaceful group of hunter gatherers who eventually sold their land to incoming Dutch and Irish settlers and migrated to Pennsylvania.  The new colonists turned the region
column3: part of the New Barbadoes Township
column4: into five large farm lots
column5: conjoined by two main roads - Paramus and Saddle River - and named it "slooterdam" (after a V-shaped sluice-like fishing weir built in the Passaic River by the Lenni Lenape).  The name stuck until 1791.  In the 1800s
column6: these five lots became nine smaller lots
column7: and three new roads - Fair Lawn Avenue
column8: Lincoln Avenue
column9: and Prospect Street - were constructed to encourage mobility between them.  Eighty houses were built by 1861
column10: and the renamed Small Lots
column11: now a part of the Saddle River Township and home to multiple vegetable and fruit farms and dairies
column12: became an agricultural community.  Berdan Avenue
column13: a new road located near five Berdan family farms
column14: was soon added and Victorian homes were built alongside it and in nearby areas.  The grandest of the estates
column15: perched atop a hill by Small Lots Road was David Acker's estate "Fairlawn
column16:
from which the township gets its name (Images of America, Page 7).
Rapid suburban development of the town occurred in three sections: the River Road-Fair Lawn Avenue area known as Memorial Park"
column17: the area at Lincoln Avenue and Wagaraw Road known as "Columbus Heights"
column18: and the area east of the railroad and south of Broadway
column19: known as Warren Point. The development of this section was catalyzed by the "establishment of a post office
column21: and a trolley to the Hudson River" (Images of America

column2: Fair Lawn residents were displeased about the schooling situation as part of Saddle River Township; the schools were either dilapidated or too far away for Fair Lawn residents
column3: and citizens felt that they were not getting schools comparable to the tax money they were paying. As such
column4: a movement to separate from Saddle River Township was born. Fair Lawn residents petitioned to the state
column5: asking to incorporate as an independent borough
column6: and in April 1924
column7: the borough of Fair Lawn was voted into existence.

column2: an NJ Transit train derailed and crashed into a pasta factory
column3: killing the train's engineer. The derailment resulted from a group of teens who had tampered with the tracks. Two of the five youths charged with the crime were convicted of manslaughter for their roles in the incident and were given five-year sentences in a state correctional facility.

The Memorial Park neighborhood borders the Passaic River and contains the park next to Memorial Middle School named Memorial Park which houses a World War II Memorial commemorating those who fought in the war. The park is the terminus of the annual Memorial Day parade and the site of the Memorial pool and beach as well as the Independence Day fireworks show. Residential gentrification is occurring with the leveling of two-family rental housing for more modern single-family housing in this area.

column1: Fair Lawn has a longstanding tradition of ethnic diversity and a tolerance for people of different ethnicities and religious faiths. Continuing steady immigration from Eurasia
column2: Asia
column3: Europe
column4: and Latin America has transformed Fair Lawn into an international melting pot
column5: and over 50 languages and dialects are spoken in the borough.

column1: Fair Lawn has been a center for Jewish culture over a period spanning several decades. Since the early 2000s
column2: the Orthodox Jewish population has been increasing significantly and has replaced the earlier decreases in members of the non-Orthodox Jewish sects. After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991
column3: Russian Jews began to migrate to Fair Lawn. Fair Lawn's Jewish American population has therefore maintained an at least one-third presence overall for several decades. Russian Jews were then followed by Russian Orthodox Christians. Over 10% of the borough's population is of Russian descent
column4: the highest of any community in New Jersey
column5: and increasing with continued migration of Russian Americans from Brooklyn. The size of Fair Lawn's Russian American presence prompted an April Fool's satire titled
column6: "Putin Moves Against Fair Lawn". Fair Lawn also has the largest Israeli American community in Bergen County. On November 22
column8: the Jewish Historical Society of North Jersey celebrated the grand opening of a permanent home at 17-10 River Road in Fair Lawn
column9: after being housed at various locations
column10: mostly in neighboring Paterson
column11: for decades.Fair Lawn has historically also had a large Italian American population
column13: but this number is decreasing as the descendants of the original Italian immigrants are being displaced by immigrants from around the globe.

column14: and the Polish American population is also growing. The public library in Fair Lawn holds storytelling programs in Hindi and Hebrew languages

column20: and the (Italian American) Cosmos Club of Fair Lawn. Several Filipino organizations are based in Fair Lawn. Between the 2010 Census and the 2013-2017 American Community Survey

column1: Fair Lawn operates within the Faulkner Act (formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law) under the Council-Manager plan E form of New Jersey municipal government
column2: as implemented as of January 1
column4: based on direct petition. The borough is one of 42 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form of government. The governing body is comprised of a five-member Borough Council. Members of the Borough Council serve four-year terms in office and are elected at-large in partisan elections in odd-numbered years on a staggered basis
column5: with either two or three seats coming up for election every other year as part of the November general election. All policy making power is concentrated in the council. At an annual reorganization meeting held after each election
column6: the council selects a mayor
column8: and a deputy mayor for community affairs from among its members. The mayor presides over its meetings with no separate policy-making power. A borough manager is appointed by the council to serve as the municipal chief executive and administrative official.As of 2020
column9: the members of the Borough Council are Mayor Kurt Peluso (D

column11: 2023; term as mayor ends 2021)
column13: term on council and as deputy mayor ends 2021)
column14: Deputy Mayor of Community Affairs Gail Friedberg Rottenstrich (D
column15: term on council and as deputy mayor ends 2021)
column19: the Borough Council appointed Cristina Cutrone to fill the seat expiring in December 2019 that was vacated by Mayor Lisa Swain when she took office in the General Assembly; Kurt Peluso replaced Swain as mayor and in turn Gail Rottenstrich replaced him as deputy mayor. Cutrone served on the council on an interim basis until the November 2018 general election
column20: when she was elected to serve the balance of the term of office.Standard Borough Council meetings are televised on local cable TV when held in the council chambers in the Fair Lawn Municipal Building. Work sessions
column21: where laws are discussed and prepared for adoption

column1: The Fair Lawn Public Schools serves students in kindergarten through twelfth grade. As of the 2018–19 school year
column2: the district
column3: comprised of nine schools
column4: had an enrollment of 5
column5: 138 students and 409.5 classroom teachers (on an FTE basis)
column6: for a student–teacher ratio of 12.5:1. Schools in the district (with 2018–19 enrollment data from the National Center for Education Statistics.) are

column1: John A. Forrest Elementary School (286 students; grades K-5)
Henry B. Milnes Elementary School (497; K-5)

column2: 490; 9-12).  In both the 1990–91 and 1997-98 school years
column3: Fair Lawn High School received the National Blue Ribbon Award from the United States Department of Education
column4: the highest honor that an American school can achieve. In 2016
column5: Lyncrest Elementary School was one of ten schools in New Jersey recognized as a National Blue Ribbon School by the United States Department of Education
column6: a recognition celebrating excellence in academics. Henry B. Milnes Elementary School was one of nine schools in New Jersey honored in 2020 by the National Blue Ribbon Schools Program.In December 2014
column7: Fair Lawn voters approved by a greater than 2-to-1 margin a $12.8 million expansion and capital improvement referendum to be implemented by the Fair Lawn Public Schools. The referendum funds the initiation within two years of a full-day kindergarten in the district
column8: a program offered by most districts countywide
column9: as well as a roof replacement program at six schools. The expenditures will include $2.2 million in state aid
column10: with the remaining $10.6 million covered by bonds issued by the school system. The full-day kindergarten program is slated to begin in September 2016.Public school students from the borough
column11: and all of Bergen County
column12: are eligible to attend the secondary education programs offered by the Bergen County Technical Schools
column13: which include the Bergen County Academies in Hackensack
column14: and the Bergen Tech campus in Teterboro or Paramus. The district offers programs on a shared-time or full-time basis
column15: with admission based on a selective application process and tuition covered by the student's home school district.St. Anne School is a Catholic elementary school that operates under the supervision of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark.

column1: Fair Lawn has an all-volunteer fire department. The department has four stations—Company 1 on George Street
Company 2 at Route 208 South (before Maple Avenue Bridge)
Company 3 located at the corner of Plaza Road and Rosalie Street and
Company 4 on Radburn Road. Fair Lawn residents are served by the all volunteer Fair Lawn Volunteer Ambulance
column2: Inc.
column3: which provides 24/7 emergency medical services. This service is equipped with four state of the art ambulances stocked with all necessary supplies to handle any medical emergency. Fair Lawn is also served by the all-volunteer Fair Lawn Rescue Squad. The squad provides heavy rescue and hazardous materials (HAZMAT) services to the residents and businesses of the borough.Fair Lawn also has a police department that was founded in 1930. In 2014
column4: the department responded to over 400 calls.

column1: Fair Lawn is interwoven by a robust network of roads. As of May 2010
column2: the borough had a total of 99.60 miles (160.29 km) of roadways
column3: of which 84.00 miles (135.18 km) were maintained by the municipality
column4: 11.13 miles (17.91 km) by Bergen County and 4.47 miles (7.19 km) by the New Jersey Department of Transportation.Fair Lawn is traversed by two state highways
column6: which connects Fair Lawn to New York City via the George Washington Bridge
column8: which links Fair Lawn to the New York City bypass highway Interstate 287.

column1: Fair Lawn has several main roads crossing through it forming a rough 3x3 grid. Running north–south are Saddle River Road
column2: Plaza Road
column3: and River Road (County Route 507) while Broadway
column4: Morlot Avenue
column5: and Fair Lawn Avenue run east–west
column6: and Route 208 runs northwest–southeast. Running east–west between and parallel to Morlot and Fair Lawn Avenues is Berdan Avenue
column7: a residential thoroughfare which is bisected by Route 208 into two discontinuous segments
column8: the western one of which contains Fair Lawn High School.

column1: Broadway becomes Route 4 heading into Paramus and is less than 10 miles (16 km) from the George Washington Bridge.Fair Lawn Avenue is considered the borough's main street
column2: containing its borough hall
column3: police station
column4: and public library. The road goes west over the Passaic River into Paterson
column6: Fair Lawn Avenue ends at Saddle River Road
column7: which through Dunkerhook Park becomes Dunkerhook Road
column8: and becomes Century Road once in Paramus
column9: at Paramus Road. The intersection of Fair Lawn Avenue and Plaza Road form what could be considered a "town center"
column10: with several shopping plazas and the Radburn train station all within walking distance. In October 2015
column11: a community meeting was held to discuss a vision for this corridor. Other commercial areas include Broadway and River Road.

column1: Route 208 has its southern terminus in Fair Lawn and bisects the borough from the northwest to the southeast
column2: where it eventually merges with Broadway to become Route 4 just west of Fair Lawn's border with Paramus. Taken the other direction
column3: Route 208 flows northwest to Interstate 287 in Oakland. Numerous commercial establishments and office buildings line Route 208 along the northwestern half of this limited access highway's trajectory through Fair Lawn.

column2: Saddle River Road goes through the eastern side of Fair Lawn and into Saddle Brook
column3: where it provides a link to both the Garden State Parkway and Interstate 80.  North of Route 4
column4: Saddle River Road provides a link to Glen Rock.

column1: Fair Lawn uses a street address numbering system in which most Fair Lawn addresses are given hyphenated numbers
column2: such as 10-13 Some Street. Less than 1% of addresses in New Jersey use this kind of numbering system and Fair Lawn's nearly 10
column3: 000 hyphenated addresses account for nearly half of them. This numbering system is also used in Queens
column4: New York City. Exceptions to this numbering system generally exist on the Glen Rock
column6: and Saddle Brook sides of Fair Lawn and within the Radburn development. The system
column7: dating at least as far back as the 1930s
column8: was designed to allow emergency personnel to quickly locate addresses.The first numbers (before the dash) correspond to block-distances from Broadway (on streets that run North-South) and to the numbered streets in the borough (example: 2nd Street
column9: 17th Street
column10: etc.) on the streets that run East-West; with the highest numbers being in the low 40s
column11: and the lowest numbers being 0-30
column12: etc. Addresses south of Broadway / Route 4 start with a zero and a hyphen
column13: which can cause confusion with those unfamiliar with the grid system. Most GPS systems and online address entry forms do not accept the dash
column14: though addresses entered without the dash are typically handled properly.

column1: Fair Lawn is served by the Radburn and Broadway train stations on the NJ Transit Bergen County Line
column2: which offers service to Lower Manhattan via the Hoboken Terminal
column3: and connections at Secaucus Junction to Penn Station in Midtown Manhattan and to most other NJ Transit train lines.NJ Transit buses include the 144
column7: 164 and 196 routes to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan; the 171 and 175 to the George Washington Bridge Bus Terminal; and the 746
column8: 758 and 770 lines
column9: offering local service.Spanish Transportation and its jitney buses / guaguas operate out of its terminal located one block from the NJ Transit Paterson Terminal on Broadway in downtown Paterson. The two lines
column10: the Broadway and Main Street jitneys
column11: begin at its respective Main Terminal on Broadway
column12: with the Broadway-Washington Heights line heading west on Broadway with frequent local stops then continuing onto Route 4 before crossing the George Washington Bridge and dropping commuters off in front of the George Washington Bridge Bus Terminal with access to the A Train. The Main Street-42nd Street route heads south down Main Street and makes frequent local stops through Clifton and Passaic
column13: then makes sporadic non-local stops until undergoing the Lincoln Tunnel
column14: dropping commuters off via 42nd Street in front of the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

column1: Fair Lawn lies 20 miles (32 km) north of Newark Liberty International Airport

column1: The Passaic River Fishing Weir is a prominent archaeological feature just north of the Fair Lawn Avenue Bridge. It was constructed by Lenape tribe members and is the best-preserved of several such weirs on the Passaic River.Fair Lawn is home to the following locations on the National Register of Historic Places:
G. V. H. Berdan House - 1219 River Road (added 1983)
Richard J. Berdan House - 24-07 Fair Lawn Avenue (added 1983): Purchased by Richard J. Berdan in 1808
column2: the home was constructed for the Bogert family circa 1750.

column1: Peter Garretson House - 4-02 River Road (added 1974): With a homestead that dates back to 1719
column2: the sandstone house is one of the oldest surviving structures in Bergen County. The Garretson Forge and Farm Restoration operates the site
column3: owned by the county
column4: as a farm museum.

column1: Naugle House - 42-49 Dunkerhook Road (added 1983): Constructed in 1776
column2: the home was visited by the Marquis de Lafayette. The site was purchased by the borough in 2010 for $1.7 million
column3: and a plan has been formulated to repair the home and preserve the grounds as open space.

column1: Radburn - Irregular pattern between Radburn Road and Erie RR. tracks (added 1975)
Jacob Vanderbeck Jr. House - 41-25 Dunkerhook Road (added 1983): Constructed in Dutch stone by Jacob Vanderbeck in the 1750s
column2: the house has had a number of prominent owners
column3: including Fair Lawn mayor and Assemblyman Richard Vander Plaat. Owned by a developer who has sought to use the site to construct a large-scale assisted-living facility
column4: the house has been listed on Preservation New Jersey's 2013 list of the 10 Most Endangered Historic Places in New Jersey.Fair Lawn also has a close association with two historic areas along the Saddle River in Paramus. One is the Easton Tower
column5: a Bergen County historic site that consists of a stone tower and a small dam which mark the site of the colonial-era Jacob Zabriskie mill and the 19th-20th centuries-era Arcola community park. Another is the Dunkerhook community
column6: focused around the New Jersey designated historic road
column7: Dunkerhook Road. The western section of the community includes the Naugle House and the Jacob Vanderbeck Jr. House
column8: and the eastern section included a slave and free-African American community that consisted of a school
column9: a cemetery
column10: a church
column11: and houses including the now-demolished Zabriskie Tenant House.
